node.text:
"I would describe cryptocurrencies as a limited supply of nothing."

John Paulson—who's famous bet against subprime housing made him and investors $20 billion—says crypto is a "worthless" bubble and he calls SPACs, one of the hottest investing tools, a losing proposition.

Paulson told @bloombergtv in an interview on "Bloomberg Wealth with David Rubenstein" he's more concerned about rising prices. The rapidly expanding money supply could push inflation rates well above current expectations, he said, and gold, which he’s backed for years, is primed for its moment.

Paulson’s dismissal of crypto is sure to attract critics after digital assets vastly outperformed gold in recent years. Watch the full episode Tuesday at 9pm ET on BloombergTV and read the Big Take in our stories.

node.title: Cryptocurrencies are a Bubble, Says Billionaire Paulson

node.text: Frackers in America’s largest oil field are letting massive amounts of methane spill into the atmosphere. These scientists and activists are trying to find the leaks and get them plugged before they cook the planet further.

node.title: The Methane Hunters Racing to Change the Course of Global Warming

node.text:
Astra + Pfizer = ?
Moderna + Sinovac = ?

In some countries, people have received a mixture of Covid vaccines. Nicole Sy breaks down what that could mean for the world's vaccinated, and those still waiting on their first shot. (via @quicktake)

node.title: What Happens When You Mix Covid Vaccines?

node.text: Few people have lost as much money as quickly as Bill Hwang. In March, the previously unknown Wall Street whale and his family firm, Archegos, triggered losses of more than $20 billion in just two days. The result was one of the most spectacular implosions in modern financial history. (via @businessweek)

node.title: How Archegos Capital Cost Wall Street $20 Billion

node.text:
China's growing ranks of rural entrepreneurs are getting rich peddling their produce on social media. 

One of the scene's stars is Jin Guowei, aka Brother Pomegranate — an internet sensation with 7.3 million followers and 300 million yuan ($46 million) of sales in 2020. (video via @quicktake)

node.title: Livestreaming Farmers Earn Millions From Fruit on China’s TikTok

node.text:
In almost every way measurable, millennials in the U.S. at 40 are doing worse financially than the generations that came before them.

Fewer millennials own homes than their parents did at their age. They have more debt — especially student debt. They simply aren’t as wealthy. 

Now, if predictions of a long, post-Covid economic boom are to be believed, this may be the last opportunity an entire generation has to build wealth before heading off into retirement.

node.title: Millennials Are Running Out of Time to Build Wealth to Retire

node.text: When employees at software company 10Pines want a raise, they pitch their co-workers, not their boss. Here's what happens when a firm uses "radical transparency" to attract and retain talent.

node.title: Would You Let Your Colleagues Decide Your Salary?

node.text:
While the "15-minute city" model promotes neighborhood-level urban planning, Sweden is pursuing a hyper-local twist: a scheme to redesign every street in the nation.

For more, read the report by @citylab: bloomberg.com/citylab/design

node.text:
Two of the world's wealthiest individuals will attempt to fly into space just nine days apart.

Here's how their space trips compare. (via @quicktake)

node.title: Billionaire Space Race: Branson vs. Bezos

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 04, 2021. May be an image of airplane, outdoors and text.

node.text:
Corporate travel as we've known it is a thing of the past.

A Bloomberg survey of 45 large companies in the U.S., Europe and Asia found 84% plan to slash travel budgets post-pandemic. The majority are aiming for cuts of between 20% and 40%.

The future isn't just Zoom calls. Businesses are investing in augmented reality and slashing stipends as they seek out ways to reduce their spending on trips. Tap the link in our bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 04, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says '"Cryptocurrencies area bubble. Iwould describe them as limited supply of nothing. John Paulson President, Paulson & Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Ever since billionaire investor John Paulson bet against the U.S. home market last decade, people keep asking him about the next big trade.

In an exclusive interview with Bloomberg TV, he shared his thoughts for the hottest investments of this era. “I wouldn’t recommend anyone invest in cryptocurrencies,” Paulson said adding SPACs will also be a losing proposition.

The investor said he thinks cryptocurrencies are a bubble that will “eventually prove to be worthless.” Link in bio to read the full interview.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business in Sotheby's. May be an image of one or more people and text that says 'The shredded Banksy is back (with a much higher price) Bloomberg'.

node.text:
You probably remember the scene.

In 2018, a painting by Banksy began to self-destruct on the auction block, seconds after it was sold for £1 million ($1.4 million). Then, about halfway through, the shredder hidden in its frame stopped — or jammed.
 
Now "Love is in the Bin" is up for auction again with a pre-sale estimate of up to £6 million ($8.4 million), the highest of any Banksy piece to date.

If it hits the target, it will have appreciated 500% in three years. More at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 03, 2021. May be an image of car and text that says 'Amazon's answer its driver shortage: recruit pot smokers prime Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Pot smokers, Amazon wants you.

The company is advising its delivery partners to prominently advertise that they don’t screen applicants for marijuana use, according to correspondence reviewed by Bloomberg and interviews with four business owners. 

Doing so can boost the number of job applicants by as much as 400%, Amazon says in one message, without explaining how it came up with the statistic. Conversely, the company says screening for marijuana cuts the prospective worker pool by up to 30%. Tap the link in our bio for more. 

📷: Artur Widak/Getty Images

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 03, 2021. May be an image of phone and text that says 'Millennials and Gen Zare hooked on this $46 billion shopping app Κ.'.

node.text:
Search for Klarna on TikTok and you’ll find young people making light of the debt they’ve racked up using the wildly popular “buy now, pay later” app that’s expanding rapidly in the U.S. and elsewhere.

However, this apparently carefree attitude toward credit has disturbed financial regulators. Another worry is that shoppers don’t always fully understand what they’re signing up to.

Klarna pushes back against the idea that it spurs overspending, but greater scrutiny is inevitable as the company approaches the stock market. For more, tap the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 03, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'AstraZeneca's Covid vaccine tech shows promiseas a cancer shot Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Scientists behind the University of Oxford and AstraZeneca Covid-19 shot are using the same technology to try to develop a therapeutic cancer vaccine, with promising results seen in animal studies.

A new study found that a two-dose regimen reduced tumor size and improved survival rates in mice. Human trials are set to begin this year. 

Vaccine research has taken a leap forward in the wake of the pandemic, raising the prospect of new treatments for cancer and other diseases. Read in full via the link in our bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business in Hoboken, New Jersey. May be an image of one or more people, body of water and text that says 'Torrential rain from Ida kills at least 40inU.S. Northeast Bloomberg'.

node.text:
At least 40 people are now known to have died on the East Coast as the remnants of Hurricane Ida hammered the region with heavy rain.
 
Downpours flooded subway stations, roads, playgrounds and homes in New York and New Jersey, leaving airports and commuter rail services struggling to resume service. The dead include a number of residents living in basement apartments. 

Tap the link in our bio for the latest.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business in Auckland, New Zealand. May be an image of one or more people, people standing, outdoors and text that says 'POLICE wwwwwiiw!!!!! POLIC New Zealand police kill "terrorist" after he stabs six people Bloomberg'.

node.text:
BREAKING: New Zealand authorities said they shot and killed a violent extremist who was under their surveillance after he entered a supermarket and stabbed six shoppers.

Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern described the incident as a terror attack. She said the man was a Sri Lankan national who was inspired by the Islamic State group.

Tap the link in our bio for the latest.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 02, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child, outdoors and text that says 'Gangs are running Haiti, filling a vacuum after years of collapse Bloomberg'.

node.text:
The misery of Haiti — the poorest and most unequal nation in the Americas, facing natural disaster on top of political crisis — has been well-documented. But to grasp the challenge, look to the once-teeming neighborhood of Martissant, now hollowed-out, abandoned and covered in gray dust. It’s a choke point in the hands of rival gangs who’ve driven thousands from their homes, closed a major hospital, shut down fuel distribution routes and barred farmers from the markets.

Elections are being planned to replace assassinated President Jovenel Moise and humanitarian aid is being rushed to those hit by the earthquake and subsequent tropical storm. But it’s clear there will be no solution in Haiti until the government can tame the gangs.

“In Haiti, more than a failing state we have a non-existent state,” says Joseph Harold Pierre, an economist. Read more at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 02, 2021. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'America's richest already have a plan to escape Biden's tax increase tax me if you can! USDOT3300858 taxt Bloomberg Wealth'.

node.text:
“Entirely legal, easy to exploit, and politically very hard to close.” That’s how one expert describes private placement life insurance, a niche strategy that was already gaining popularity among the very rich.

As long as assets are held in a PPLI policy, they escape taxes. When a policyholder dies, heirs inherit the PPLI’s contents tax-free. Those perks strike at the heart of Biden’s plans to get the very wealthy to pay more taxes on their investments, especially on capital gains that currently aren’t levied if assets are held until death.

The threat of increased taxes isn’t the only factor sparking interest in the policies. A little-noticed change in U.S. insurance law at the end of 2020 also makes them a more powerful tool. Find out more at the link in bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business on September 02, 2021. May be an image of text.

node.text:
Nomura wants to stub out smoking among its staff — and it doesn't care if you're WFH.
 
Japan's biggest brokerage sent a memo to employees outlining plans to close all of its smoking rooms by the end of December. Remote workers are also expected to toe the line and refrain from lighting up during office hours. 

About a fifth of Japanese smokers said they were consuming more cigarettes as a result of being at home during the pandemic, according to a March poll. Nomura says its rules will be based on mutual trust. Tap the link in our bio for more.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Bloomberg Business in Cincinnati with @businessweek, and @bloombergequality. May be an image of 1 person, standing, outdoors and text that says 'Cincinnati, once a model for police reform, has slipped back backintooldhabits into Bloomberg'.

node.text:
Until recently, Cincinnati had been heralded as a model for community policing. After the 2014 shooting of Michael Brown, a Black teenager, in Ferguson, Mo., news outlets across the country lauded the CPD as a case study in how police departments could work with and better serve Black residents. 

The CPD operated under the Collaborative Agreement — a series of reforms including an order for officers to move away from arresting petty thieves and low-level drug dealers in favor of “community problem-oriented policing.” That meant addressing issues that cause people to commit crimes in the first place.

The reforms didn’t come without resistance and took years to be fully implemented, but for a time the arrangement worked. From 2008 to 2014, felony arrests declined 41.9%, according to a University of Cincinnati study.

In recent years, however, city officials seem to have become complacent, and the police department, according to critics, has fallen into old habits. Full story at the link in our bio.

Photo: Jahi Chikwendiu/Getty
